Young, Assistant Secretary.Captain Clement Jones, Assistant Secretary,.Printed for the War Cabinet. March 1917.SECRET. Man-Power:Report of lord rhondda'sCommittee.1. THE War Cabinet decided that-Lord Milner and Mr. Henderson should have full authority todetermine all outstanding questions arising out of theReport of Lord Rhondda's Committee (War Cabinet, 103,Minute 2). The War Cabinet impressed on them that inany question affecting the construction of ships or marineengines, their decision should be based on the principlethat it is a vital and paramount national war interest thatthere shall be no reduction in the output of the yards.Note. The questions reserved for consideration under war Cabinet, 103, Minute 3 (b) and (c), were settled at a special Meeting on Tuesday, the 27thMarch. (Paper G.T.-301, Appendix I.)Purchase of 2. With reference to War Cabinet, 102, Minute 15, in view ofShipping. the need for a prompt decision, the Shipping Controller asked theWar Cabinet for authority to make further purchases in the UnitedStates of America for delivery in 1917-18, involving an additional sum of about 8,000,0002.The War Cabinet authorised the Shipping Controller to make this purchase subject to arrangement as to the time of payment and subject to the same condition, to continue topurchase further when opportunity arose.(Initialled) D. G2, Whitehall Gardens, S.W.,March 29, 1917.APPENDIX I.G.T.-301. -Notes of a Meeting held at 10, Downing Street, on Tuesday, March 27, 1917,at 10'45 a.m.Present:The Prime Minister,.Mr. Henderson.Mr. Bonar Law.Lieutenant-General Sir CE. M. Macready.Brigadier-General A. C. Geddes.Lord RhonddaMr. Hayes Eisner.Sir Horace Monro.Mr. I. G. Gibbon.Mr. G. M. "Young, Assistant Secretary.1. THE draft of the amending Military Service Bill was considered, and it wasdecided that a single-clause Bill dealing with Medical Re-examination (Clause 3, of draft Bill as circulated) should be introduced immediately with a view to its beingpassed into law before the Easter recess.2. On the question of extending to resident aliens of Allied countries theliability to serve with the forces, Mr. Bonar Law reported that he had asked the EoreignOffice to ascertain from the present Russian Government whether they hold the sameviews as their predecessors on this subject.(Initialled) G.
